text: Helmien Willie Rambaldo (born 13 November 1980) is a former Dutch international cricketer whose career for the Dutch national side spanned from 1998 to 2013. She served as the team's captain in One Day International (ODI) matches from 2007 to 2011, and during that period also captained the Netherlands in its inaugural Test and Twenty20 International games. Born in The Hague, Rambaldo's older sister, Caroline Rambaldo, also played international cricket for the Netherlands.Caroline Rambaldo – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Both sisters played their club cricket for Quick Haag (nl).Netherlands / Players / Helmien Rambaldo – ESPNcricinfo. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Helmien Rambaldo made her ODI debut in July 1998, aged only 17, scoring two runs against Denmark in what was the first ODI to be played in Germany (at the Mikkelberg-Kunst-und-Cricket Center).Women's ODI matches played by Helmien Rambaldo – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Slotting into the side as a top-order batsman, her next matches in that format came at the 1999 European Championship in Denmark. Her performance there was unremarkable, with only 16 runs from three innings,Batting and fielding for Netherlands Women, Women's European Championship 1999 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. but she maintained her place in the Dutch squad for its next major tournament, the 2000 World Cup in New Zealand. At the World Cup, Rambaldo was selected for only three of a possible seven matches, but topscored with 38 against Sri Lanka, opening the batting with Maartje Köster.Netherlands Women v Sri Lanka Women, CricInfo Women's World Cup 2000/01 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. When the Netherlands toured Pakistan in April 2001, Rambaldo featured in six of their seven ODIs against the Pakistani national team, and finished the tournament behind only Pauline te Beest and Carolien Salomons for runs scored.Women's ODI batting and fielding for Netherlands Women, Netherlands Women in Pakistan 2000/01 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. In the sixth game, as the ninth player brought on to bowl, she finished 2/13 from five overs – her first ODI wickets and what were to be her best bowling figures.Pakistan Women v Netherlands Women, Netherlands Women in Pakistan 2000/01 (6th ODI) – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. In 2003, Rambaldo moved to South Africa to study sport science at Western Cape's Stellenbosch University. She continued to play for the Netherlands throughout her degree, but also played cricket for her university and for Boland in the South African provincial set-up, until graduating in 2006.(25 September 2010). "Rambaldo excited about return to South Africa" – ICC Europe. Retrieved 29 June 2015. In July and August 2007, South Africa went on a tour of the Netherlands, playing three ODIs and a Test – the first (and so far only) Test match played by any Dutch team, men or women.(27 July 2007). "Test history ... but all eyes on the ODIs" – ESPNcricinfo. Retrieved 29 June 2015. The Test was Rambaldo's first international match as captain, with Carolien Salomons having stepped down the previous year. She would remain the side's captain until she stepped down prior to the 2012 season."Helmien Rambaldo stopt als captain" – Koninklijke Nederlandse Cricket Bond. Retrieved 29 June 2015. At the 2008 World Cup Qualifier in South Africa, Rambaldo played a key role in helping the Netherlands to a semi-final. In a group-stage game against Bermuda, she was player of the match, scoring 59 from 55 balls opening with Violet Wattenberg, and helping the Dutch team to a 196-run win.Bermuda Women v Netherlands Women, ICC Women's World Cup Qualifying Series 2007/08 (Pool A) – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Later in the tournament, in the semi- final against Pakistan, Rambaldo caught Pakistani number-eleven batsman Sadia Yousuf at short cover to give Lotte Egging a hat-trick, the first by a Dutchwoman.Netherlands Women v Pakistan Women, ICC Women's World Cup Qualifying Series 2007/08 (Semi-Final) – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Rambaldo only recorded one half-century in her ODI career, 67 against Sri Lanka in the 2010 Women's Cricket Challenge in South Africa.Netherlands Women v Sri Lanka Women, ICC Women's Cricket Challenge 2010/11 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Her next-best had been 46 against Japan in the 2003 IWCC Trophy.Netherlands Women v Japan Women, International Women's Cricket Council Trophy 2003 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 29 June 2015. Rambaldo finished her career with 723 runs from 46 ODIs, in both cases behind only Pauline te Beest and Caroline Salomons for the Netherlands.Netherlands Women / Records / Women's One-Day Internationals / Most runs – ESPNcricinfo. Retrieved 29 June 2015.Netherlands Women / Records / Women's One-Day Internationals / Most matches – ESPNcricinfo. Retrieved 29 June 2015. She captained the Netherlands in one Test, 25 ODIs, and ten T20Is, with the team winning only a single match under her captaincy in those formats – an ODI against Ireland at the 2011 European Championship, and only by two wickets.(17 August 2011). "Netherlands prevail in tense match" – ESPNcricinfo.
